title: 109_hr4867
content: The "Puerto Rico Democracy Act of 2006" establishes a federally sanctioned process for Puerto Rico's self-determination, including an initial plebiscite and subsequent procedures. It also addresses applicable laws, requirements, and the availability of funds for the self-determination process. The Congress acknowledges past actions by Presidents Bush and Clinton regarding Puerto Rico's political status through memorandums and executive orders. The President's Task Force on Puerto Rico's Status was established to identify options for the territory's political future that align with US laws. President George W. Bush required regular reports on progress towards determining Puerto Rico's ultimate status. In 2005, the Task Force recommended that Congress take action within a year. The President's Task Force on Puerto Rico's Status recommended that Congress hold a federally sanctioned plebiscite for Puerto Ricans to vote on remaining a US territory or pursuing a permanent nonterritorial status. If the latter is chosen, a subsequent plebiscite should be held to choose between two nonterritorial status options. If Puerto Rico chooses a permanent nonterritorial status, Congress should allow a plebiscite for the people to select between two options. If they opt to remain a US territory, periodic plebiscites should be held to keep Congress informed of their wishes. Federally sanctioned process for Puerto Rico's self-determination, including an initial plebiscite and subsequent procedures. The Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will conduct a plebiscite in Puerto Rico to choose between continuing the current territorial status or pursuing a path towards a permanent nonterritorial status. Instructions on the ballot will specify that only one option should be marked, and ballots with multiple options marked will not be counted. The Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will conduct plebiscites at intervals of every 8 years if the majority vote favors the existing territorial status. If the majority vote favors a permanent nonterritorial status, additional plebiscites will be held. If a majority vote in a plebiscite favors permanent nonterritorial status, the Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will conduct another plebiscite offering only two options: Statehood or becoming a sovereign nation. The Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will conduct a plebiscite with two options: Statehood or becoming a sovereign nation. Voters must choose only one option, and ballots with more than one option marked will not be counted. If a majority vote favors permanent nonterritorial status, another plebiscite will be held. If a majority vote favors permanent nonterritorial status in the first plebiscite, another plebiscite will be held during the 111th Congress, but no later than December 31, 2009. If a majority vote in a plebiscite favors permanent nonterritorial status, another plebiscite will be held not later than 2 years after the certification of the majority vote. SEC. 4. APPLICABLE LAWS AND OTHER REQUIREMENTS. All Federal laws applicable to the election of the Resident Commissioner of Puerto Rico also apply to any plebiscite held under this Act. Federal courts have exclusive jurisdiction over legal claims related to this Act. The Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will issue rules for the plebiscites. Eligible voters under electoral laws can participate in the plebiscites. The Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will issue rules and regulations for plebiscites under this Act. Eligible voters include those under Puerto Rico's electoral laws and US citizens born in Puerto Rico who meet Commission requirements. Absentee ballots can be requested before the plebiscite. The Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will certify plebiscite results to the President and Congress. A report will be submitted after the second plebiscite, prepared in consultation with key Puerto Rican officials. After the second plebiscite, the President's Task Force on Puerto Rico's Status will submit a report to Congress detailing measures to implement the chosen nonterritorial status option, in consultation with key Puerto Rican officials. During the period from October 1, 2006, until all plebiscites required by the Act are completed, up to $5,000,000 from funds allocated to Puerto Rico may be used by the State Elections Commission for plebiscite expenses, including voter education materials approved by the President's Task Force on Puerto Rico's Status.
